==Mutual Recursion== I would not connect mutual recursion in this way with divergence respectively non-termination. This can also happen with single recursion. Its rather the case that sometimes, in bigger projects, mutual recursion naturally comes up.
[[User:Janburse|Janburse]] ([[User talk:Janburse|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Janburse|contribs]]) 20:25, 2 April 2014 (UTC)

Lots of presentation discussion to be had! [[User:WikiLeaksGroup|WikiLeaksGroup]] ([[User talk:WikiLeaksGroup|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/WikiLeaksGroup|contribs]]) 20:38, 2 April 2014 (UTC)
==Facebook== Discussion Copied from Facebook, 18th March-24th of March:
Claire Porter: If you's meet the keep me up to date and I'll try by some miracle to contribute from ny x
Kasia Peel: sorry i completely didn't realise i'd been added to this group! but i think by the looks of things we are contributing on a sort of individual basis for the wiki and discussing it with the other group on the wiki discussion page. my page it RedGebsKasia, so since we get marked for our contributions we could always chat on their as me and elizabeth have been. then i think its more the presentation stuff that we will have to be meeting up for since we actually do that together
Kasia Peel: i should be able to still meet up also, on monday i have a break between 1 and 2?
Elizabeth Ross: I can do between 1 and 2 too, but we should definitely try and meet up. Is there a different time that would suit on Monday, maybe after 4pm?
Caroline Grace Malcolm: I can do after 4
Debbie Morrison: Yes, great idea! Where….? x
Elizabeth Ross: Shall we meet in social study? Kasia and I might be a bit late due to the film screening, but not too much.
Elizabeth Ross: I was looking at the topics covered so far and I don't think anyone is really covering the sense of belonging one can get through online groups and communities. Do you think we should look at this? I already have a few notes. Obviously we can talk about it more tomorrow but just something to think about. [[User:ButtonsElizabeth|ButtonsElizabeth]] ([[User talk:ButtonsElizabeth|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ButtonsElizabeth|contribs]]) 20:49, 2 April 2014 (UTC)
Discussion Copied from Facebook, 31st of March:
Claire Porter: Booked a group study room for 12 on thursday, should all get an email sent to you about it.
Caroline Grace Malcolm: I will get there at about 12:15 and need to leave at 1:45 because of classes but that should be ok
Claire Porter: Also its room 10 by the way
== Presentations ==
Just some stuff to maybe think about ahead of us meeting up tomorrow. I wrote a good chunk of the SNSs section and so was maybe thinking we could do a group exercise on their Facebook or social media usage, getting everyone to discuss how they are affected by impression management, blurred boundaries ect and maybe see if they have examples to share. We could get the ball rolling by doing it ourselves first, or at least one of us.
I also think we should try and link in as much of our real life experience as possible to make the presentation as engaging and interesting as possible. [[User:ButtonsElizabeth|ButtonsElizabeth]] ([[User talk:ButtonsElizabeth|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ButtonsElizabeth|contribs]]) 20:55, 2 April 2014 (UTC)
And this might be a good video to start the whole presentation with- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=10K137WU9gw [[User:ButtonsElizabeth|ButtonsElizabeth]] ([[User talk:ButtonsElizabeth|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ButtonsElizabeth|contribs]]) 21:10, 2 April 2014 (UTC)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xua1JXd5pK0. I think this one we could reflect on just how big a deal online identity is if there are web blogs and videos giving advice. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FGFF8lJM8mk. And I thought this one highlights really well a lot of the points that have been brought up throughout the whole page, not just SNSs [[User:ButtonsElizabeth|ButtonsElizabeth]] ([[User talk:ButtonsElizabeth|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ButtonsElizabeth|contribs]]) 21:22, 2 April 2014 (UTC)
We should brainstorm using the topics we have covered and (I agree) personal experience. Then we can decide which ideas will work best given the time frame and environment. [[User:Debsi91|Debsi91]] ([[User talk:Debsi91|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Debsi91|contribs]]) 10:11, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
Was really happy with our meeting today, lots of progress made! Just to confirm on time allocation for each person in the belonging section it was two minutes yeah, before I start writing my part on fan culture? [[User:Clairepporter|Clairepporter]] ([[User talk:Clairepporter|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Clairepporter|contribs]]) 15:38, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
I am having an issue with this section that when I post something it wont save or appear [[User:Caroline Malcolm|Caroline Malcolm]] ([[User talk:Caroline Malcolm|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Caroline Malcolm|contribs]]) 15:39, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
Two minutes is perfect. I think I have finished with my section, I am worried it is a little on the short side but I don't want to waffle. Any feedback would be appreciated if you can think of anything positive/negative. Presentations ahoy! [[User:Debsi91|Debsi91]] ([[User talk:Debsi91|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Debsi91|contribs]]) 23:58, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
Ok I just managed to save something. I think today went really well and our content is good. I think come Monday it will be more clear because we can start creating the official presentation and practice our deliverance. I also think it is really important that we ensure that the presentation is well organised and set out in a logical way that is purposeful in order that it does not look messy. But I think come Monday we can make sure that happens as we pull together all the work and create the final piece. [[User:Caroline Malcolm|Caroline Malcolm]] ([[User talk:Caroline Malcolm|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Caroline Malcolm|contribs]]) 15:42, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
I agree, once we have all of our own content prepared for the presentation I think it should fit together nicely. [[User:Clairepporter|Clairepporter]] ([[User talk:Clairepporter|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Clairepporter|contribs]]) 15:44, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
I think roughly two minutes will be good. Our mock run through on Monday will help though. Is everyone happy with what they have to write, or shall I put up the rough order sheet document we were working on today? [[User:ButtonsElizabeth|ButtonsElizabeth]] ([[User talk:ButtonsElizabeth|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/ButtonsElizabeth|contribs]]) 20:07, 3 April 2014 (UTC)

Hey guys! If anyone has any questions or any help let me know on here or on my discussion page! Thanks!
I love to collaborate and help edit different articles!

Hello there! My name is Charlotte and I'm a student at the University of Stirling studying English with Film & Media. I also act and enjoy working both in front of and behind the camera.
This is my Wikipedia user page for my University module FMS9A4 on Digital Media & Culture. Feel free to start a discussion with me and we can get some good stuff going on here :) [[User:LittleBlondeLottie|LittleBlondeLottie]] ([[User talk:LittleBlondeLottie|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/LittleBlondeLottie|contribs]])

Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 00:31, 3 April 2014 (UTC)

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Mr Roberts YDT!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 00:34, 3 April 2014 (UTC)

==Sophistica==

{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Foreign Key|next=Drop Table}}
__TOC__
The ALTER TABLE command modifies column definitions and table constraints 'on the fly'. This means existing definitions are extended, changed or deleted or existing data is casted to a different type or existing data is evaluated against the new definitions. -- change column definitions ALTER TABLE { ADD | ALTER } [ COLUMN ] ; ALTER TABLE { DROP } [ COLUMN ] ; -- change table constraints ALTER TABLE { ADD | ALTER } CONSTRAINT ; ALTER TABLE { DROP } CONSTRAINT ; The following examples are based on the test table ''t1''. CREATE TABLE t1 ( id NUMERIC PRIMARY KEY, col_1 CHAR(4) ); == Columns == The syntax of the ADD COLUMN and ALTER COLUMN phrases are similar to the one shown in the [[Structured_Query_Language/Create_Table#Column_Definition|create table page]]. === Add a Column === Existing tables can be extended by additional columns with the ADD COLUMN phrase. Within this phrase all options of the original Create Table statement are available: data type, default value, NOT NULL, Primary Key, Unique, Foreign Key, Check. -- add a new column with any characteristic ALTER TABLE t1 ADD COLUMN col_2 VARCHAR(100) CHECK (length(col_2) > 5); -- Oracle: The key word 'COLUMN' is not allowed. === Alter the Characteristic of a Column === With the ALTER COLUMN phrase some characteristics of an existing column can be changed :*data type :*DEFAULT clause :*NOT NULL clause. The new definitions must be compatible with the old existing data. If you change for example the data type from VARCHAR to NUMERIC this action can only be successful if it is possible to cast '''all''' existing VARCHAR data to NUMERIC - the casting of 'xyz' will fail. Casting in the direction from NUMERIC to VARCHAR will be successful as long as the width of the VARCHAR is large enought to store the result. Hint: Concerning the change of the characteristics of columns some implementations ignore the syntax of the SQL standard and use other keywords like 'MODIFY'. ==== Change the Data Type ==== ALTER TABLE t1 ALTER COLUMN col_1 SET DATA TYPE NUMERIC; ==== Change the DEFAULT Clause ==== ALTER TABLE t1 ALTER COLUMN col_1 SET DEFAULT 'n/a'; ==== Change the NOT NULL Clause ==== ALTER TABLE t1 ALTER COLUMN col_1 SET NOT NULL; ALTER TABLE t1 ALTER COLUMN col_1 DROP NOT NULL; === Drop a Column === Columns can be dropped from existing tables. ALTER TABLE t1 DROP COLUMN col_2; -- Oracle: The key word 'COLUMN' is mandatory. Hint: As an extention to the SQL standard some implementations offer a RENAME or SET INVISIBLE command. == Table Constraints == Table constraints can be added, modified or dropped. The syntax is similar to that shown on the [[Structured_Query_Language/Create_Table#Table_Constraint|create table page]]. === Add a Table Constraint === ALTER TABLE t1 ADD CONSTRAINT t1_col_1_unique UNIQUE (col_1); === Alter a Table Constraint === ALTER TABLE t1 ALTER CONSTRAINT t1_col_1_unique UNIQUE (col_1); Hint: Concerning the change of table constraints some implementations ignore the syntax of the SQL standard and use other keywords like 'MODIFY'. === Drop a Table Constraint === ALTER TABLE t1 DROP CONSTRAINT t1_col_1_unique; -- MySQL: Not supported. There is only a 'DROP FOREIGN KEY'. Hint: As an extention to the SQL standard some implementations offer an ENABLE / DISABLE command for constraints. == Exercises ==
Add a column 'col_3' to the table 't1': numeric, not null.
{{ExerciseSolution|width=100%|text= ALTER TABLE t1 ADD COLUMN col_3 NUMERIC NOT NULL; }}
Add a Foreign Key from table 't1' column 'col_3' to table 'person' column 'id'.
{{ExerciseSolution|width=100%|text= ALTER TABLE t1 ADD CONSTRAINT t1_col_3_fk FOREIGN KEY (col_3) REFERENCES person (id); }}
{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Foreign Key|next=Drop Table}} {{BookCat}}

{{TopNav|prev=Alter Table|next=Temporary Table}} {{BookCat}}
__TOC__

{{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Alter Table|next=Temporary Table}}
__TOC__
The DROP TABLE command removes the definition and all data of the named table from the database. DROP TABLE ; The command handles the table as a whole. It will not fire any trigger. But it considers [[Structured_Query_Language/Foreign_Key#DROP_TABLE_.2F_TRUNCATE_TABLE|Foreign Key definitions]]. If any other table referes to the table to be dropped, the DROP TABLE command will fail. The Foreign Key definition must be [[Structured_Query_Language/Alter_Table#Drop_a_Table_Constraint|dropped]] first. As the DROP TABLE command handles the table as a whole, it is very fast. {{BookCat}}

< [[IB]]‎ | [[IB/Group 3|Group 3]]‎ | [[IB/Group 3/History|History]]‎ | [[IB/Group 3/History/Assessment|Assessment]] | [[IB/Group 3/History/Assessment/Paper 2|Paper 2]]

= The Live-CD = The GNU Health Demo Database is available as Live-CD. This gives interested users the option to run GNU Health on their own PC, and, if desired, install the GNU Health demo database directly from the CD.
Similar as the demo database, the live-CD is an ongoing project and it will be adapting to the each new GNU Health version. The clinical history will also grow with time. == Download the Live-CD == The Live-CD was built on [https://susestudio.com/ SUSEStudio], and is currently available with the following flavours: * openSUSE 13.1 / KDE4 / 32bit: [https://susestudio.com/appliance/edit/1083253 GNU Health 2.4.1] * openSUSE 13.1 / KDE4 / 32bit: [https://susestudio.com/a/7hReQg/gnu-health-2-6-kde-4-32bit GNU Health 2.6] Unlike the full version of openSUSE, the Live-CD contains only packages that are required to run GNU Health. Feel free to add required programs later on from the openSUSE repositories == Install the Live-CD == In order to use the Live-CD, you have to install it on a CD or a USB stick. === USB-Stick / Hard Disk Image === The hard disk image comes as packed raw format. After download, first unpack the *.tar.gz file * On Linux/Mac-OS, use your favorite archiving program, or use 'tar -xvzf *tar.gz' from the command line * On Windows, use an advanced packer like 7-Zip After unpacking, you have to install the RAW-file to a stick. [http://en.opensuse.org/Live_USB_stick See instructions]. Note: When booting the first time from the USB-Stick, the boot process takes a bit longer, as the stick is being optimized (data and swap space creation). Second boot will be much quicker. === ISO-Image / CD === If you have downloaded the ISO image to burn a CD, you can find the relevant instructions [http://en.opensuse.org/SDB:Download_help#Burn_the_ISO_image.28s.29 here]. == Install the Live-CD to your hard drive == The Live-CD offers the option to install the system and the GNU Health Demo-DB to your hard drive. The relevant program can be found in the 'My Computer' Section of the start menu (the little green button on the lower left corner of the screen). = Virtual Machine Images = The live-CD is available in various container formats that allow easy integration into a virtual environment. Currently the following formats are published: * Xen Guest (.img) * OVF Virtual Machine / ESXI (.ovf) * VMware Workstation / VirtualBox (.vmdk) * SUSE Cloud / OpenStack / KVM (.qcow2) * Hyper-V Virtual Hard Disk (.vhd) == Running the Virtual Machine as Server == Several times the question came up 'How can I access my Live-CD from another desktop'? This should not be too difficult if you consider some points. The following example bases on Virtualbox, but should be similar on other virtual environments: * When setting up the network, make sure you select 'Bridged Network'. In this case the virtual box will receive the IP-Address from your DHCP-Server, not from the host-machine * Make sure the network-name of your virtual box is updated to your DDNS-Server. Even better, you may assign a fix network address to your virtual box, say 192.168.2.100 * Try to ping the box from an external client on the network: open a console and type: ping 192.168.2.100 * If this works, and your GNUHealth server is running, check if you can access the server from outside: telnet 192.168.2.100 8000
If this works, everything is good.
If not, its time to check the firewall settings of your box. From the Start Menu, select System -> Administration -> YaST. Enter the password for 'root': tryton , and go to 'firewall Settings'. Check the external zone (right interface name?) or even add an exception for the 192.168.2.100/24 network == Adjustmends== * You may want to change the language and keyboard to your preferred setting. From the Start Menu, select System -> Administration -> YaST. Enter the password for 'root': tryton . You have reached the administration settings. From the 'System' Section select 'Language' to change the primary language. * You may want to run an online update. From the Start Menu, select System -> Administration -> YaST. Enter the password for 'root': tryton . You have reached the administration settings. From the 'Software' Section select 'Online-Update'. * You may want to install additional software. From the Start Menu, select System -> Administration -> YaST. Enter the password for 'root': tryton . You have reached the administration settings. From the 'Software' Section select 'Software Management'.

page.title: Professionalism/David Lappa and the Lawrence Livermore National Lab

revision.text:
David Lappa was a long-term employee at [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Livermore_National_Laboratory Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory], a nuclear weapons lab primarily funded by the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Energy Department of Energy (DOE)]. Lappa blew the whistle on deliberate mishandling of plutonium at the facility. The subsequent retaliation from his colleagues became so severe that he eventually left the lab. David Lappa's experience is similar to the mistreatment of other whistleblowers at DOE facilities. These cases are symptoms of the culture at DOE, but they also share common elements with whistleblowing cases in all organizations. == David Lappa== [[File:LLNL Aerial View.jpg|thumb|left|border|Aerial View of the Lawrence Livermore National Labratory]]David Lappa worked as an engineer at [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Livermore_National_Laboratory Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL)] at the University of California for 19 years. In the summer of 1997, he was appointed to an Internal Investigation Committee that examined the safe handling of nuclear materials at the facility. He was investigating the storage of plutonium, one of the most toxic substances on Earth. Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh calculated that a single pound of plutonium could kill 2 million people if spread in the atmosphere.http://www.phyast.pitt.edu/~blc/book/chapter13.html Lappa was surprised to find that lab employees were storing excessive amounts of plutonium in closed handling platforms called glove boxes. This created a danger of a criticality event, in which the plutonium would spontaneously explode and release lethal amounts of radiation. Lappa wrote a report detailing his findings and recommended that immediate action be taken to correct the problem. When Lappa sent this to his superiors, he discovered that the safety violations were intentional. He was told to ignore them and to sign off on a report stating that no violations occurred. When Lappa refused to sign, he was subjected to coercion, intimidation, and open discrimination at the lab. He was secretly given negative job performance feedback, had his pay reduced, and was denied a transfer. He was also placed in an assignment with no prospects for advancement, was later moved to a windowless office formerly used as a storage closet. Finally, his supervisor told him that management was working to fire him.Kelly, Marylia (1998). U.S.A.: Whistle Blower Wins. World Information Service on Energy That same supervisor was caught removing Lappa’s name with white-out from the report he refused to sign, saying “I’ll be damned if there’s going to be a blank signature line on the cover of this thing.” Lappa eventually filed a discrimination complaint with the Department of Labor, which began a three year legal battle. This ended in 2000, when Lappa quit his job out of stress and exhaustion and immigrated to Australia. Throughout this episode, DOE failed to fulfill its responsibilities to Lappa. First, DOE deliberately neglected to investigate any of Lappa's claims about mishandling of plutonium for several months. Secondly, once DOE confirmed that Lappa's claims were correct, it waived $153,000 in safety violation fines that it should have levied against LLNL. Third, it systematically resisted Lappa’s requests to gain access to public documents and to DOE investigators, which hindered his civil action suit and forced him to sue. Finally, DOE spent over $300,000 of taxpayer money on legal fees against Lappa. Lappa's case is not unique in DOE, and DOE administration is aware of the problem. Two years before Lappa joined the Investigation Committee, in the summer of 1995, Secretary of Energy Hazel O'Leary enacted a series of reforms she called the "Whistleblower Initiatives." These were meant to enforce a “zero tolerance policy for reprisal” against whistleblowers. Specifically, they prevented employers from revoking a whistleblower's security clearance, placed a limit on DOE payment of litigation fees against whistleblowers, and established an "employee concerns" program to help ensure employee complaints would receive full attention from supervisors. While these reforms were well-intentioned, cases like Lappa's show that they have failed to reduce hostility towards whistleblowers. On May 23rd, 2000, the Senate Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the Committee on Commerce held a a congressional hearing on whistleblowing in DOE. During the hearing, Lappa's case was used as a prime example of the dysfunction of the Whistleblower Initiatives. The Subcommittee concluded that the DOE has a clear conflict of interest by independently enforcing its zero tolerance policies and acting as a willing co-defendant against an internal whistleblower. The DOE consistently ignored its own policies and demonstrated that it is unable to self-regulate. == Other Whistle-blowers at DOE== [[File:US_Department_of_Energy_seal.png|thumb|right|border|Department of Energy Seal]]There have been many whistleblowers in DOE nuclear waste and energy labs. The security lapses identified by these whistleblowers often endanger public and national safety, but most of the informers still experience retaliation. Below are five recent examples of severe whistleblower retaliation at DOE. ===== [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Levernier Richard Levernier] ===== ''Nuclear Security Professional''
Levernier reported weaknesses in DOE's plans to protect U.S. nuclear facilities after 9/11. DOE revoked his security clearance and demoted him to clerical work. ===== David Ridenour ===== ''Director of Safeguards and Security at Rocky Flats Plant''
Ridenour noticed that contractors were not handling secret information properly at [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Flats_Plant Rocky Flats Plant], a nuclear weapons production facility.http://openjurist.org/397/f3d/925/ridenour-v-kaiser-hill-company-llc-a-eg-and-g-ct His superiors harassed and intimidated him in an attempt to end his interference with the contractors. Ridenour later quit his job. https://www.aclu.org/national-security/national-security-whistleblowers ===== Matt Zipoli ===== ''Security Officer at Lawrence Livermore National Labs''
Zipoli noticed a lack of protection for security officers at LLNL in the event of a terrorist attack. He also claimed that the training for security officers to help prevent such an attack was insufficient. He was fired. http://www.fas.org/news/usa/2002/nuclearsafety/zipoli012302.htm ===== Ed McCallum ===== ''Special Forces Colonel Employed at DOE''
McCallum raised concerns to his superiors about security standards in nuclear waste environments. He was placed on administrative leave and investigated. http://alamo-girl.com/02722.htm ===== Mark Graf ===== ''Program Manager of Alarm Station Operations at Rocky Flats''
Graf reported that plutonium was stored in insecure locations and in rooms that were not up to code at Rocky Flats Plant. He was subsequently moved to the night shift and had his work load doubled. This prevented him from adequately performing his job, and he was eventually fired. http://www.fas.org/news/usa/2002/nuclearsafety/graf012302.htm ==Culture at DOE== The amount of retaliation against whistleblowers at DOE suggests that the Whistleblower Initiatives set in place in 1995 are simply band-aid fixes. Whistleblowers perform an important role in protecting public safety. The Initiatives need to be revised to foster a more supportive environment for these individuals. Many of the initiatives are reactive, because they provide support for the whistleblower only after the retaliation has occurred. This results in multi-year court cases which damage the image of DOE and ruin professional relationships. Whistle-blowers need protection that will proactively eliminate retaliation. ===== DOE Supporting Retaliation ===== In a Senate hearing in 2000, a lawyer for the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_Accountability_Project Government Accountability Project], revealed that Rocky Flats Plant's law firm, Kaiser Hill, billed DOE for all fees associated with the Mark Graf court case. DOE also reimbursed all the expenses that the University of California's incurred from David Lappa's case.http://mspbwatch.files.wordpress.com/2013/03/whistleblowers-at-department-of-energy-facilities-is-there-really-zero-tolerance-for-contractor-retaliation-s-hrg-106-135.pdf This is an example of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_capture regulatory capture]. DOE is working to protect the interests of its contractors, not the public. By paying these litigation fees, DOE implicitly supports retaliation against whistleblowers. ===== Whistle-Blowers Who Were Right ===== Many of the whistleblowers's concerns, once investigated, are found to be serious threats to public safety. DOE eventually instituted new security measures in response to the complaints of both David Lappa and Mark Graf. Rocky Flats Plant updated its policies to reflect many of Graf's complaints. The DOE Investigator General examined Lappa's claims long after he reported them, and found that LLNL had violated DOE's Quality Assurance Rule.http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/04/f0/ea200012R01.pdf DOE forced LLNL to adjust their falling safety standards. These cases show that whistleblowers are valuable safeguards against [[Professionalism/Diane_Vaughan_and_the_normalization_of_deviance|normalization of deviance]], and that continuation of the hostile environment towards these individuals could lead to accidents. ==Generalizables== We can use the case of David Lappa and other informers in the DOE to make general conclusions about whistleblowing. ===What is Whistleblowing?=== The term "[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whistleblower whistleblower]" was coined by journalists in the case of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Otto_Otepka Otto Otepka], who reported misconduct in the State Department to the Senate in 1963. Otepka's case is no longer well-known, but the term stuck. It is often associated with politically-motivated informers, such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Ellsberg Daniel Ellsberg] and [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Snowden Edward Snowden], but whistleblowers like David Lappa are motivated by safety or public health concerns. The term itself simply means reporting illegal or immoral activity to a higher authority.http://www.psychologyandsociety.org/__assets/__original/2013/04/4.pdf Sometimes that authority is internal to an organization, and sometimes external, like a regulatory agency. Other similar terms include "ethical resistor" or informer.Glazer, Myron Peretz and Glazer, Penina Migdal. ''The Whistleblowers: Exposing Corruption in Government and Industry.'' New York: Basic Books, 1989. In almost all cases, whistleblowing is a devisive act which leads to public scrutiny of the organization or individuals who were accused. The colleagues of the whistleblower feel betrayed, and often respond with personal retaliation against the individual. These cases are highly emotional and are frequently highlighted by the media. Movies such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erin_Brockovich_(film) Erin Brokovich], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Whistleblower The Whistleblower], [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Insider_(film) The Insider], and [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silkwood Silkwood] portray how whistleblowers are threatened and intimidated by former colleagues and friends. ===The Components of a Whistleblowing Case=== Several common components are evident throughout whistleblowing cases, including those at the DOE. The first component is a work environment in which employees are conscious of wrongdoing in the organization, but refuse to report it. The illegal or immoral activity may be perpetrated by management, in which case employees are cowed into silence. Some employees may feel that it is not their responsibility to report the activity, or don't feel that their actions will make a difference. These are all examples of the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bystander_effect Bystander Effect]. Secondly, the informer feels that he or she has only two options: silence, or blowing the whistle. Two Australian lawyers identified this phenomenon in an article in the Journal of Business Ethics.Teo, H., & Caspersz, D. (2011). Dissenting Discourse: Exploring Alternatives to the Whistleblowing/Silence Dichotomy. Journal of Business Ethics, 237-249. Retrieved from Journal of Business Ethics It occurs when the organization provides no viable options to resolve the problem internally, or when management is hostile to complaints. In a 1989 study of American whistleblowers, social scientists Glazer and Glazer found that ethical resistors are often successful employees who believed strongly in the ideals of their organization. They feel shocked and betrayed when they find no internal avenues to resolve grievances or are told to ignore the issue. Finally, the whistleblower's former colleagues and friends retaliate. This is a form groupthink, a term that Irving Janis coined in 1972.Janis, I. (1972). ''Victims of groupthink : a psychological study of foreign-policy decisions and fiascoes.'' Boston: Houghton Mifflin. The effects of groupthink include collective rationalization of assumptions, belief in the morality of the group, and pressure on dissenters. In response to the stressful situation following the accusation, members of the group draw closer together by rejecting the whistleblower. They defend the innocence of the group instead of working to discover if there is truth in the accusation. In a 2010 study of nurse whistleblowers, one former informant was reported as saying “I keep my mouth shut these days. I’m a different person now… In hindsight I wouldn’t have said anything… it wasn’t worth it really, emotionally”.http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20626488 She reported an inappropriate sexual relationship between a doctor and a patient. Another study of whistleblowing retaliation in 1986 found that 17% of informants lost their homes, 15% divorced after the incident, and 10% attempted suicide.Vinten, G. (1994). ''Whistleblowing : subversion or corporate citizenship?'' New York: St Martin's Press. ===Professionalism=== This analysis suggests an addition to the definition of professionalism. We contend that an important attribute of a professional is the ability to admit one's mistakes. In a whistleblowing case, this means rejecting groupthink, objectively reflecting on the morality of one's past actions, and being able to admit fault. It also means being able to forgive the person who made the accusation. Everyone, even professionals, will occasionally commit errors in judgement. It takes a great deal of courage and self knowledge to admit that error and to not shoot the messenger who publicly accused you of it. It is much harder for individuals to reject groupthink in an organization where management implicitly approves of retaliation, such as DOE. Reforming the Whistleblower Initiatives may encourage individual employees to act as professionals and end hostility towards whistleblowers. ==References==

Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.

Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Coogorsailing!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 19:00, 3 April 2014 (UTC)

Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? == Wikitext == Regarding your post on [[Wikibooks:Reading room/Technical Assistance]], I'd recommend reading [[Using Wikibooks/Wiki-Markup]]. In addition selecting ''Browse'' or ''Random book'' on the menu on the left of the screen and just investigating other books will help.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 00:06, 11 April 2014 (UTC) :Also [[Help:Contents]] has a more detailed look at everything.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 00:10, 11 April 2014 (UTC) == Importer Flag == I'm attempting to get rights to import content from English Wikipedia. If I should get the flag I would like some guidance on how to, because I'm unsure based on the page [[wikibooks:importers]] :You'll see that I have changed it so that you now have importer rights. [[Special:Import]] is the page to go to. Make sure you select the correct project (''w'' for Wikipedia). Then enter the correct title of the Wikipedia page. Ensure the first check box is checked. To transfer to a new page in your book choose ''(Main)'' from the drop-down box. Enter your reasons for the import in the ''Comments'' field. Finally enter ''Topology'' in the ''Destination root page'' field. This will import the page from Wikipedia (let's call it ''Blob'') to Topology/Blob. Sometimes there can be problems especially if it's a big page or a page with hundreds of revisions - in that case leave a message in the [[Wikibooks:Reading_room]] and someone will try to help. Hope this all makes sense.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 00:36, 22 April 2014 (UTC) Thank you! I'll try it out tonight. [[User:Knittedbees|Knittedbees]] ([[User talk:Knittedbees|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Knittedbees|contribs]]) 00:42, 22 April 2014 (UTC) :I just noticed your first attempt. It is possible to import directly to your book if you select ''Main'' from the drop-down box instead of ''Transwiki''. I think the import didn't work because the actual page on Wikipedia is ''Eilenberg–Steenrod axioms'' with the long hyphen. --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 01:04, 22 April 2014 (UTC) :I have succeeded in importing that page now - [[Topology/Eilenberg–Steenrod axioms]]. I'll delete the other attempts. I don't even have the long hyphen (–) on my keyboard (only the short (-) so I had to copy and paste from Wikipedia. I should also add that imported pages will often be full of red links which you'll have to remove or change the links within the book.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 01:10, 22 April 2014 (UTC) :I see you managed this time. I had just imported it also so it looks strange when you click on ''History'' as there are now 3 different entries for each past edit because it has been imported 3 times - I don't think it matters. I'll leave you to it and if you have any further problems hopefully someone will be around to help out - I'm off to bed.--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 01:16, 22 April 2014 (UTC) Great, thanks for setting me up, I'll just have to watch my punctuation. I can tell this will take some effort to get into wikibook style but still a lot easier than working from scratch. [[User:Knittedbees|Knittedbees]] ([[User talk:Knittedbees|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Knittedbees|contribs]]) 01:14, 22 April 2014 (UTC)

What have you been doing on the Blender NtP discussion page? [[Special:Contributions/2A01:E35:8AB6:1930:5DF3:270E:2BD4:9CD3|2A01:E35:8AB6:1930:5DF3:270E:2BD4:9CD3]] ([[User talk:2A01:E35:8AB6:1930:5DF3:270E:2BD4:9CD3|discuss]]) 20:50, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
I ask because it seems like this user deleted part of my comment for no explained reason. Note that I was not signed in at the time, nor when I made the above comment.[[User:Serpinium|Serpinium]] ([[User talk:Serpinium|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Serpinium|contribs]]) 20:56, 3 April 2014 (UTC)
Oh wait, I just got confused between the "cur" and "prev" history changes. This user is actually me, ''adding'' content and not deleting.[[User:Serpinium|Serpinium]] ([[User talk:Serpinium|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Serpinium|contribs]]) 21:00, 3 April 2014 (UTC)

A '''normed vector space''' <math>(V,|\cdot|)</math> is a vector space ''V'' with a function <math>|\cdot|:V\times V\to \mathbb{R}</math> that represents the length of a vector, called a norm.
==Definition==
We know the vector space defintion, so we need to define the norm function. <math>|\cdot|</math> is a norm if these three conditions hold.
1. Only the zero vector has zero length, with all others being positive. <math>|v|\geq 0, |v|=0\iff v=0</math> for all <math>v\in V</math>.
2. For <math>a\in \mathbb{R}</math> and <math>v\in V</math> we have <math>|av|=|a||v|</math>.
3. The triangle inequality holds: <math>|v+w|\leq |v|+|w|</math> for all <math>v,w\in V</math>.
==Example==
For a given <math>n\in \mathbb{N}</math> we know that <math>\mathbb{R}^n</math> is a vector space and its norm can be defined to be <math>|v-w|=d(v,w)</math> ie. <math>|v|=d(v,0)</math>. This is not unusual, in fact we say that a norm '''induces''' a metric with the first equation. So normed vector spaces are always metric spaces. Let's prove this.
==Theorem==
Normed vector spaces are metric spaces.
Proof
It suffices to show that <math>d(v,w)=|v-w|</math> satisfies the metric axioms. Let <math>u,v,w\in V</math>
1. <math>d(v,w)=|v-w|\geq 0</math> holds by definition and <math>d(v,w)=|v-w|=0\iff v-w=0 \iff v=w</math> as required.
2. <math>d(v,w)=|v-w|=|-1||w-v|=|w-v|=d(w,v)</math>
3. <math>d(u,v)+d(v,w)=|u-v|+|v-w|\geq |u-v+v-w|=d(u,w)</math> so the triangle inequality translates correctly.
Since the axioms hold, we conclude that ''V'' is a metric space.
==Exercises== (under construction)

Sorry for the inconvenience." . Q Set Availablenotes=$S($G(^ATM(100)):"100",1:"") Set Availablenotes=Availablenotes_" "_$S($G(^ATM(500)):"500",1:"") Set Availablenotes=Availablenotes_" "_$S($G(^ATM(1000)):"1000",1:"") W #,!,"Only ",Availablenotes," note(s) are available" R !,"Enter the Amount :",Amount:60 I '$T D .
