@import "//ja.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User:Rxy/vector-PreviouslyFontSettings.css&action=raw&ctype=text/css";

==Setting up your compiler== To do any useful OpenMP programming, you will need a compiler that supports it. * The [http://gcc.gnu.org/ GNU C Compiler] (GCC) has OpenMP 3.1 support since version 4.7. This compiler comes with practically any Linux system; for instance, on Ubuntu you can install it (and a set of related tools) with sudo apt-get install build-essential. To find out the version of GCC that you have installed, issue gcc --version on the command line. * The Intel C Compiler supports OpenMP. * The Clang compiler, [https://trac.macports.org/wiki/UsingTheRightCompiler shipped with Apple's Xcode], does not support OpenMP as of April 2014, but an [http://clang-omp.github.io/ experimental version by Intel] does. * Microsoft Visual C++ apparently has limited support for OpenMP, depending on the version. * The LLVM-GCC compiler, shipped with older versions of Apple's Xcode, does not support OpenMP. The [http://openmp.org/wp/openmp-compilers/ OpenMP website] has a more complete list of compilers with OpenMP support. Apart from a compiler, we'll also be using the make tool in this book. You can do without if you want to use a different build system.
#REDIRECT [[OpenMP/Reductions]]

So how do I put a page up for speedy deletion? The relevant section contains no how-to information at all. [[User:Qwertyus|Qwertyus]] ([[User talk:Qwertyus|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Qwertyus|contribs]]) 15:16, 5 April 2014 (UTC) :You're right. To tag a page for speedy deletion add the following: <nowiki>{{delete|reason why here}}</nowiki>. For other templates useful to Wikibooks see [[Wikibooks:Templates]].--[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|<sup>talk</sup>]] 16:14, 5 April 2014 (UTC) ::Added it. Thanks. [[User:Qwertyus|Qwertyus]] ([[User talk:Qwertyus|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Qwertyus|contribs]]) 16:41, 5 April 2014 (UTC)

revision.comment: Created page with "[[Image:AMD Opteron Six Cores.jpg|thumb|right|A six-core AMD processor. OpenMP programs can run on all six cores simultaneously.]] Welcome to the Wikibook ''Parallel Programmi..."
revision.text:
[[Image:AMD Opteron Six Cores.jpg|thumb|right|A six-core AMD processor. OpenMP programs can run on all six cores simultaneously.]] Welcome to the Wikibook ''Parallel Programming with OpenMP''! This short book serves as a tutorial for the [[:w:en:OpenMP|OpenMP]] framework for parallel programming, using the C programming language. It discusses how to easily create parallel programs in C, or add parallel constructs to existing sequential code to make it run faster on multiprocessor and multicore machines.
* This book assumes you are already familiar with either C or C++. While the examples are in C, OpenMP works very similarly in C++ and the techniques discussed usually carry over to C++ with few modifications. We won't discuss OpenMP support in Fortran. * The examples in this book are mostly numerical algorithms, but it is not too heavy on the math. OpenMP is popular in the scientific computing world, but it can just as easily be employed in games, server programs, or any other program that has to do a lot of computation. * The emphasis in this book is on the OpenMP 3 standard and programming for multicore CPUs. While OpenMP 4 adds interesting new features including support for vector instructions, GPUs and accelerators, OpenMP 3 is better supported by current C and C++ compilers.
==Contents== * [[/Overview|Overview of OpenMP]] * [[/Setup|Setting up]] * [[/Loops|Parallel loops]] * [[/Reductions|Reductions: summing floating point numbers]] * [[/Tasks|Parallel tasks and recursion]]
#REDIRECT [[OpenMP/Overview]]
#REDIRECT [[OpenMP/Setup]]
#REDIRECT [[OpenMP/Reductions]]

=Tajikistan=
* Tajikistan was a region of the former Soviet Union which became independent in 1991. Meter stamps with former Soviet Union markings (“CCCP”, hammer and sickle logo, etc) continued to be used after independence. Although it is probable meter stamps inscribed Tadzhikistan are in use, examples are not known to us. ----

Experienced enterprise software developer (Java, C#, SQL, HTML 4, Javascript, Perl 4, bash, Linux, MS-Windows) in Research Triangle Park area of North Carolina, U.S.
Have also used, studied, or otherwise played around with:
* Haskell * Prolog * Eiffel * Self * emacs LISP * FORTRAN, COBOL, PL/1 * PowerShell
M.S. Comp. Sci., 1994.
As of April, 2014, a Python neophyte.

revision.text:
{{recipe}} [[Category:Chicken recipes]] [[Image:Locrio de Pollo (Dominicano).jpg|right|200px]] A Locrio is a common Dominican dish, similar to paella. Like Paella, there are many variations. The main point is to have a little tomato sauce/paste for coloring, and some caramelized sugar. In that way it is similar to the Trinidadian Pilau.
Like Paella, the rice at the bottom should be toasted or browned, but not burnt. This browned rice is called "concon". You're not considered a good cook until you can do this.
== Ingredients == * 4 lbs (1.8kg) [[Cookbook:Chicken|Chicken]] cut up, alternatively one can use guineafowl, rabbit, Dominican salami, pork chops, or other meat, cut in pieces. * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|C]] Olives (pitted, preferably) or Capers. * ¼ C Oil for frying * 2 Tbsp Oil, used later when rice is almost done * 1 Tbsp sugar ===Liquids and rice=== * 4 C [[Cookbook:Rice|rice]] * 5¼ C Chicken [[Cookbook:Stock|stock]] or water * ¼ C tomato paste (mix it in the water/stock until smooth) ===The Sofrito=== * ½ C finely diced [[Cookbook:Celery|celery]] * ½ C finely diced [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] * 2 cloves of [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]], chopped. ===Seasonings=== * 1 tsp salt or to taste * 1 tsp [[Cookbook:Thyme|thyme]] * ½ tsp Oregano (if desired) * 1 tsp ground black pepper
== Procedure == This recipe is in three steps: first caramelize the sugar, fry the meat / vegetables, then cook it with the rice.
===Caramelizing the sugar=== #Put the oil in the pot, and heat on high heat #Put in the tablespoon of sugar. #It will melt, then turn brown.
Note: pay close attention and don't let the sugar burn. Adding the chicken brings the temperature down. Also don't use plastic utensils to stir the sugar, since it will be at around 400F (200C), which will melt plastic. Use wooden or metal utensils, but the sugar may stick to it.
===Frying the meat=== #Add the meat (chicken, guineafowl, rabbit, etc.) and let it brown on both sides. #Remove the meat #Fry the garlic, onions, and celery
===Cooking rice=== #Add rice, meat, and all liquid #Add the salt, pepper, and thyme #Add olives or capers. #Although it is not authentic, you can add 1 tsp Ajinomoto (味の素). Some Dominicans add "Sazón Completo" which has MSG in it anyways. #Check the seasoning. If the salt is good, add an extra ½ tsp of salt. This is because the rice will absorb some of the salt, and it will come out a bit flat in the end. #On high heat, bring to a boil, and let it boil, stirring occasionally until the water is absorbed. (Note: the high heat is needed to bring the rice temperature up so that it cooks. If you lower the flame at this point, the rice might not cook all the way). #Cover, lower the heat, and let it cook 15 minutes. #Uncover, sprinkle 2 Tbsp oil on top, and stir so that the uncooked rice on top goes to the bottom #Give another 5 minutes. #If rice still not cooked, give it another stir and another 5 minutes. #Turn heat on high for a couple of minutes to brown (toast) the rice on bottom (sometimes it does this by itself during the main cooking so you don't have to do this. Experience will tell. #Serve.
== Notes == #If the rice doesn't cook, but all the water was absorbed, you can separate the rice from the meat, and put it in a bowl, and give it 5 minutes on high in the microwave. Often there wasn't enough heat to cook the rice. #It is also helpful to put a sheet or two of aluminium foil over the pot before putting the lid on. That helps seal the lid and keep the heat / steam from escaping. Rice often comes out better. #Dominicans tend to cook the rice on the dry side: rice will be cooked through, but not too watery. The ratio should be 4 C rice to 5½ C liquid (some locrio recipes ask for 7 or 8 cups of liquid, which makes things mushy). If you have tomato sauce instead of tomato paste, you can use that also, as long as the ratios are the same (e.g. 1 C tomato sauce to 4½ C water/stock; which makes a total of 5½ C liquid). #Some people deep fry the meat separately, remove the excess oil, and then caramelize the sugar. #The ingredients of the sofrito vary, and can be made in advance. Some add cilantro, bell peppers, culantro (''Eryngium foetidum'' a.k.a. recao, culantro coyote, etc.) and other aromatics to it. #Other vegetables such as 1 cup of cubed auyama (squash) sometimes are added with the rice. #Almost any meat can be used. Pork chops (smoked), cubed Dominican Salami, cubed ham or spam, Arrenque (smoked dried herring, pre-soaked in warm water to remove some salt, but cut the amount of salt you use), canned sardines, Vienna Sausages, shellfish (mariscos) and if in desperation, ground beef, meatballs, hot dogs, etc. can also be used. One can use 2 lbs of chicken gizzards also, but gizzards need to be boiled (or pressure cooked) until tender first. #Some people use Sazón Completo for the seasoning. #One can take the skin off the chicken before frying it. #Instead of chicken stock, some people throw in a bullion cube (sopapilla).
[[Category:Meat recipes]] [[Category:Rice recipes]] [[Category:Pan fried recipes]] [[Category:Main course recipes]] [[Category:Recipes with images]] [[Category:Recipes with metric units]] [[Category:Dominican recipes]]

Visit our VR Pro Shop

VirtualRailroader

Basic Trainz

Basic Trainz is a community project hosted by Virtual Railroader. Send us articles, tutorials, or tips for inclusion. We will provide editing and formatting for consistency. If you already have suitable material posted elsewhere, send us the link(s) and we will add it (them) here.

File format. Virtual Railroader is provided in Adobe Acrobat Portable Document Format (PDF) format. The files are around 5 MB in size and require Acrobat Reader, available free from Adobe. You can read the file online or download/save it to your hard drive for reading offline and printing.

For best results. With Acrobat version 4 or higher, and the right web browser, Virtual Railroader issues will open quickly, just like web pages. We have successfully used Microsoft Internet Explorer version 5.5. We highly recommend Acrobat version 6 (or higher) for superior rendition of text and linework.

revision.comment: /* GROUP PO: Special stamps generated only by machines in Post Offices */ --~~~~
revision.text:
=Thailand= * The first postage meters were used in 1952. * All stamps are inscribed “THAILAND”. * Essays from 1928 with the country’s former name, “SIAM”, exist. * The stamps are grouped according to appearance and usage: :: A – Franks with outer frame line and separate town mark :: B – Digital stamps with 2D barcode :: PO – Stamps generated only by special Post Office machines :: PV – Variable rate stamps generated by self-service vending machines
---- ==GROUP A: Franks with outer frame line and separate town mark ==
[[File: Thailand stamp type A1.jpg|left|350px]] '''A1. Universal “MultiValue” ''' (MV), 1 May 1952. : Horizontal frank with simulated perforation outer border and straight inner border. : Country name in curved panel at top with triangular ornaments in the upper corners. : M# with “U” prefix in boxes at bottom with “POSTES” between. : Value figures variable in thickness. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 00oo ::::::::::::::::: '''a. Post Office stamp'''. Meter U1 was used in the Bangkok Central Post Office. [[File: Thailand stamp type A2.jpg|left|360px]] '''A2. Universal''', later '''Pitney Bowes “Automax” ''' (MV), 1970. : Very similar to Type 1 but the ‘perforation holes’ in the outer frame line are smaller, and the value figures are of uniform thickness. :::::::::::::::::: '''A'''. M# with “U” prefix (Universal) :::::::::::::::::: '''B'''. M# with “P” prefix (Pitney Bowes) : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] =0.oo [[File: Thailand stamp type A3.jpg|left|330px]] '''A3. Pitney Bowes-GB “5000” '''series (MV), 1970. : Horizontal frank wider and shorter than with Types A1-A3. : Triangles in upper corners are without ornament. : M# with “P.” prefix in boxes at bottom. : Small “POSTES” breaks bottom frame line. : TM: DC, SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0.00 :::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With Thai instead of Western year date [[File: Thailand stamp type A4.jpg|left|350px]] '''A4. Kilburn''' (MV), 1979. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$50 for meter K9, much more for other meter numbers] : Square frank with single-line simulated perforation border. : Meter number and prefix in floating boxes at bottom. : M# with “K” prefix. : Ten machines only were used, most being withdrawn quite early. Meter K9 was used longest. : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 00.00 [[File: Thailand stamp type A5.jpg|left|340px]] '''A5. Hasler “Mailmaster” ''' (MV), 1980. : Very similar to Type A2 but only two parallel lines under “POSTES” instead of five. : Spacing between the TM and frank is narrower than with Type A2. : M# with “H” prefix : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 00.00 ::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With Thai instead of Western year date [[File: Thailand stamp type A6.jpg|left|330px]] '''A6. Pitney Bowes-GB “6300” ''' (MV), 1983. : Small, horizontal frank with single-line simulated perforation border. : Scrollwork ornaments at sides. : M# with “P.” prefix in lower corners. : TM: DC or SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋ 0.00 :::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With Thai instead of Western year date [[File: Thailand stamp type A7.jpg|left|350px]] '''A7. Pitney Bowes-GB “6600” ''' (MV). : Similar to Type A5 but taller. : M# with. “P” prefix : TM: DC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋ 0.00 ::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With Thai instead of Western year date [[File: Thailand stamp type A8.jpg|left|340px]] '''A8. Pitney Bowes “A/B900” '''series (MV). : Similar to Type A5 but slightly wider and with larger, 5-bank value figures. : M# with “P” prefix. : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋00.00 ::::::::::::::::: '''a'''. With Thai instead of Western year date [[File: Thailand stamp type A9.jpg|left|340px]] '''A9. Neopost Alcatel “Electronic” ''' (MV), 1995. : Horizontal frank with straight line border. : Country name in horizontal panel at top. : M# with “A” prefix at bottom flanks “BAHT” : TM: SC : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] 00.00 ---- ==GROUP B: Digital stamps with 2D barcode==
[[File: Thailand stamp type B1.jpg|left|330px]] '''B1. Pitney Bowes "DM1000" ''' (digital), December 2008. : Frameless, horizontal frank with 'paper airplane' design at top center above the baht currency symbol. : Vertical 2D barcode at far left. : ''"THAILAND POST"'' at top right above the value figures, date, and 5-digit number. : At left are a number with "P. prefix, a 6-digit number, and the town name. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] (000)0.00 ---- ==GROUP PO: Stamps generated only by special Post Office machines==
[[File: Thailand stamp type PO1A.jpg|left|200px]] [[File: Thailand stamp type PO1B.jpg|right|200px]]
'''PO1. Matsushita Electric Company''' (MV), 4 August 1987. [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] : Upright frank in red on plain adhesive tape without outer frame. : Country name in Thai at top above two horizontal bars with the value figures in between. : “POSTAGE’ breaks the upper bar. : The town mark and country name in English are at center : A transaction number and the date are at bottom. ::::::::::: '''A'''. “POSTAGE” 10 mm wide ::::::::::: '''B'''. Small “POSTAGE” 7 mm wide (''shown at right'') : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★(00)0•00 [[File: Thailand stamp type PO1point1.jpg|left|190px]]

'''PO1.1. Matsushita Electric Company''' (MV). [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][Appears to be rare] : Similar to Type PO1 but with "THAILAND" boxed at top and the post office identification boxed at center. : "POSTAGE" breaks the center box at its bottom. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ★(00)0•00 '''NOTE''': This may be an experimental design used for only a short time or only at one location. [[File: Thailand stamp type PO2A.jpg|left|320px]] [[File: Thailand stamp type PO2C.jpg|right|310px]] [[File: Thailand stamp type PO2B.jpg|left|320px]] [[File: Thailand stamp type PO2D.jpg|right|305px]]

'''PO2'''. Unidentified local manufacturer (digital), 2000. : Horizontal, unframed design printed in black on adhesive labels with serpentine 'perforations' at the sides. : Illustration of elephants at right below English country name. : Value figures below elephants, and various data including date and machine number at left. :::::::::::::::: '''A'''. Label with very faint horizontal lines [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$10] :::::::::::::::: '''B'''. Plain white label with fluorescent red stripe across top (2001) [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]][$5] :::::::::::::::: '''C'''. Plain white label with inscription in blue and red across bottom, small characters (2004) :::::::::::::::: '''D'''. As ''C'' but the characters are larger (2006) : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0.00 [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋0,000.00 (maximum 99,999.00) '''NOTE''': Sub-type PO2A labels tend to fade. Keeping them away from light has no affect. Sub-types PO2B, C, and D do not have this problem. [[File: Thailand stamp type PO3.jpg|left|280px]]
'''PO3'''. Unidentified local manufacturer (digital), 2008. : As PO2D but value figures are different, narrower and thicker, and with a wide space between the "≋" and the first digit. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] ≋ 0.00 to ≋ 0,000.00 (maximum 99,999.00) :::::::::::::: '''a'''. Value figures without "≋" '''NOTE''': Many minor variations of Types PO2 and PO3 can be found. The differences are in the font and font size and also in the image of the elephants. It is probable that Thai Post tweaks the operating system in these machines frequently. ---- ==GROUP PV: Variable-rate stamps generated only self-service vending machines==
[[File: Thailand stamp type PV1.jpg|left|295px]] '''PV1. Thailand Post in cooperation with a local university (digital), 2006. : Label imperforate along top and bottom and with serpentine 'perforations' at the sides as used with types PO2 and PO3. : With barcode at bottom above the Thailand Post logo in blue and red (as found on type PO2D). : Ten machines were trialed in the Bangkok area. : The date is printed on the label, and they are valid only on the date of purchase. : V/F: [[File:MeterCat 5 spaces.jpg|12px]] B00.00 ---- The Hasler "Mailmaster" stamp shown below is inscribed entirely in Thai except for the town name at the bottom of the town mark. The status of the stamp is uncertain, but it may be a design used for local mail only. [[File: Thailand local mail meter stamp.jpg|center|325px]] ----

revision.comment: Created page with "Recipes typical of the Dominican Republic:"
revision.text: Recipes typical of the Dominican Republic:

Vocabulary:

==Nouns== *pillow: almohada *blanket: manta *toothpaste: pasta de dientes *pajamas: pijama *book: libro *time: hora *stuffed animal: animal de peluche *shower: ducha *dream: soñar *face: cara *lights: luces *pesadilla: nightmare *despertar: wake up ==Verbs== *read: leer
*sleep: dormir
*brush: cepillar
*shower: duchar
*wash: lavar
*turn ofF: apagar
---------------------------------------------------------------- ==Present Simple:== *Mamá: Dónde estan sus pijamas? Es la hora de dormir. *Jesús: Pero no tengo sueño, no quiero ir a la cama. *Mamá: Sí vas al baño para lavar la cara y cepillar sus dientes, tal vez podemos leer un libro antes. *Jesús: Vale. ---------------------------------------------------------------- *Simple Past: *Papá: Dormiste bien anoche, hijo? *Jesús: Sí dormí bién, pero Daisy me despertó muy temprano. *Papá: Daisy, hija! Porqué despertiste a su hermano tan temprano? *Daisy: No pude dormir porque tuve una pesadilla anoche. Quise que Jesús encendió las luces! *Papá: Y lo hizó? *Daisy: Sí, y además me dio un animal de peluche también. *Papá: Que suerte que tienes un hermano tan simpatico! ---------------------------------------------------------------- Wikiotics Vocab link: http://wikiotics.org/en/Talking_with_kids-bedtime

revision.comment: wrong link? - Rejected the last text change (by [[Special:Contributions/Katyauchter|Katyauchter]]) and restored revision 2628572 by Katyauchter
revision.text:
==Nouns== * laundry: ropa sucia * room: cuarto
* kitchen: cocina
* bathroom: baño
* living room: sala (?) * sink: fregadero * toilet: baño * windows: ventana * carpet: alfombra * garbage / rubbish: basura * house: casa * mess: desorden * basket: cesta House Items:
* stove: estufa
* refrigerator: refrigerador * couch / sofa: sofá * chair: silla/ sillón * table: mesa ==Verbs== * to clean: limpiar * to wash: lavar * to vacuum: usar el vacío/ aspiadora * to take out: sacar * to put away: ordenar / recoger * recoger: pick up ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ==Simple Present== Papá: Vamos a limpiar la casa hoy! Mark, puedes sacar la basura por favor? Mark: Bueno, y después puedo mirar la tele? Papá: Sí, después de terminamos limpiar todo el desorden, podemos mirar la tele. Mark: Pero, Sara no esta ayudando! Papá: Y Sara, puedes ir al cuarto, recoger todo la ropa sucia, y ponla en la cesta? Sara: Bueno, y después, puedo tener un poco helado? ==Simple Past==

==Nouns== * dinner: la cena
* breakfast: el desayuno
* lunch: el almuerzo
* plate: el plato
* bowl: el bol (?)
* spoon: la cuchara
* fork: el tenedor
* knife: el cuchillo
* restaurant: el restaurante
* napkin / serviette: la servilleta
* manners: modales (?)
* cup: vaso / taza
==Verbs== * to serve: sevir
* to help: ayudar
* to cook: cocinar
* to go out: salir

page.title: International Postage Meter Stamp Catalog/Sint Maarten

revision.text:
=Sint Maartin=
* This island became a semi-independent nation in 2010 upon the dissolution of the Netherlands Antilles. Adhesive postage stamps inscribed "SINT MAARTIN" have been issued, but meter stamps have not yet been reported to or seen by us. We assume they do exist. ----

== Welcome! ==
[[Wikibooks:Welcome|Welcome]] to Wikibooks, Bouni2014!
[[File:Crystal Clear app kedit.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''First steps tutorial'''
'''Wikibooks is for [[WB:AGF|collaborative]] development of free [[WB:WIW|textbooks]].''' You do not need technical skills to [[Using Wikibooks|contribute]]. You can [[WB:BOLD|easily change most books]]. Please [[WB:CHAT|introduce yourself]], and let us know what [[WB:PROJECTS|interests you]]. If you already contribute at other Wikimedia projects, our [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikimedians|Wikimedia Orientation]] should quickly get you started.
(Would you like to provide [[Template talk:Bigwelcome|feedback]] on this message?)
[[File:Icon apps query.svg|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Getting help'''
* Read the [[Using Wikibooks]] book for a friendly introduction to the project, or our [[Help:Contents|help pages]] for more information. * You can get friendly help from the community in the [[WB:HELP|user assistance room]] or our [[irc:wikibooks|IRC channel]]. * Upload freely licensed files to [[commons:Wikimedia Commons|Wikimedia Commons]]. You may [[WB:RFP|request permission]] to upload [[w:fair use|fair use]] files locally. Please include author and source {{tl|information}} and a {{nowrap|{{tl|non-free use rationale}}}} for [[WB:FU|non-free]] files.
[[File:Nuvola filesystems trashcan full.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Made a mistake?'''
* You can [[WB:REVERT|restore]] a previously saved version. * Pages should follow the [[WB:NP|'''Book Title/Chapter Title''']] naming convention. * Need to rename a page? Use the ''move'' tab (is available once your account is 4 days old - until then, ask for [[WB:HELP|help]]). * To request a page be deleted, add {{tlx|delete|''your reason''}} to the top of the page. * Was a page you made deleted? Please read the [[WB:DP|deletion policy]], and check the [[Special:Log/delete|deletion log]] to find out why. Also check the [[WB:RFD|RFD]] archives if applicable. You can request undeletion at [[WB:RFU]], or ask the administrator who deleted the page.
[[File:Transmission icon.png|20px|link=|alt=]] '''Goodies, tips and tricks'''
* Please fill in [[WB:ES|the edit summary]] and [[WB:PREVIEW|preview]] your edits before saving. * Sign your name on [[WB:TALK|discussion pages]] by typing ~~~~ * User scripts can make many tasks easier. Look at the ''Gadgets'' tab of [[Special:Preferences|''my preferences'']]; check off the boxes for the scripts you want, and hit ''save''!
Thanks, --[[User:Xania|ЗAНИA]] [[Image:Flag_of_Estonia.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 11:30, 6 April 2014 (UTC)

== Description of Brine == The article says "[p]ickling brine is a moderately strong acid," but traditional pickling usually starts with a saltwater brine, often with spices added. The acidification is a result of lactic acid produced by the naturally present bacteria. Fresh pack pickling (what one will often see used by large companies) involves the pouring of a hot, spiced vinegar solution over cucumbers, but that isn't the traditional method. It's the salt in the brine that initially prevents microbial growth. Thus, I think this could be reworded to adhere to the typical definition of "pickling." ([[User:Pcwendland|Pcwendland]] ([[User talk:Pcwendland|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Pcwendland|contribs]]) 13:29, 6 April 2014 (UTC))

page.title: International Postage Meter Stamp Catalog/Tristan Da Cunha

revision.text:
=Tristan Da Cunha=
* Tristan da Cunha is part of the British overseas territory of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha. It has a population of only about 300 permanent inhabitants and so has little need for postage meters. Although it does issue traditional postage stamps - mainly for the philatelic trade - no meter stamp has ever been generated on this South Atlantic island. ----
